chapters.name: Why Source Evaluation Matters
topics: Why is it important to evaluate where information comes from — and not just whether it sounds right?
How does the quality of your sources determine the quality of your beliefs and decisions?
What happens when people accept information without checking the source — at the personal and societal level?
How has the internet made source evaluation both more important and more difficult?
What is the difference between evaluating a source and evaluating a claim — and why do you need both?
How does source evaluation protect you from manipulation by advertisers, propagandists, and scammers?
Why is source evaluation a skill that requires practice — not just a checklist?

chapters.name: Credible Institutions vs. Random Accounts
topics: What makes an institution credible — editorial standards, accountability, track record, and transparency?
How do you assess whether a news organization, university, or government agency is a reliable source?
What are the differences between institutional sources, independent journalists, and anonymous social media accounts?
Why can anonymous accounts sometimes break important stories — and how do you evaluate them when they do?
What is the difference between a primary source, a secondary source, and an aggregator — and which should you trust most?
How do you evaluate a website you've never heard of — what signals indicate credibility or the lack of it?
What role do reputation, corrections policies, and institutional memory play in making a source trustworthy?

chapters.name: Signals of Expertise and Peer Review
topics: What makes someone an expert — education, experience, publication record, or peer recognition?
How do you distinguish a genuine expert from someone who sounds authoritative but lacks credentials?
What is peer review — and why is it the gold standard for scientific and academic claims?
What are the limitations of peer review — and when has it failed to catch errors or fraud?
How do you evaluate expertise in fields you know nothing about — what shortcuts are reliable?
What is the difference between an expert giving an opinion within their field and an expert opining outside it?
How do interest groups, corporations, and governments find or fund experts to support their preferred narratives?

chapters.name: Understanding Bias and Editorial Slant
topics: What is editorial bias — and does every source have some degree of it?
How do you identify the political leaning of a news source — and what tools and ratings exist?
What is the difference between bias in story selection, bias in framing, and bias in factual reporting?
How does ownership affect editorial direction — and why does it matter who owns a news outlet?
What is the difference between a biased source and an unreliable source — and can a biased source still be factually accurate?
How do you use biased sources productively — reading across the spectrum rather than avoiding all bias?
What is false balance — and when does giving 'both sides' actually distort the truth?

chapters.name: Separating News, Opinion, and Rumor
topics: What is the difference between a news report, an opinion column, an editorial, and an analysis piece?
Why do many people confuse opinion content for news — and how do media outlets blur the line?
How do you identify whether something you're reading is reporting facts, interpreting facts, or advocating a position?
What is rumor — and how does it spread differently from verified news?
How do social media platforms collapse the distinction between news, opinion, satire, and rumor?
What is the difference between a leak, a rumor, and a sourced report — and how do you evaluate each?
How do cable news and talk radio blend news and opinion in ways that confuse audiences?

chapters.name: Evaluating Scientific and Health Claims
topics: How do you evaluate a scientific claim you encounter in the news or on social media?
What is the difference between a single study, a review article, and scientific consensus?
How do you spot cherry-picked science — when someone cites one study while ignoring a hundred others?
What are preprints — and why should you treat them differently from peer-reviewed publications?
How do pharmaceutical companies, food companies, and supplement makers use science selectively to market products?
What are the warning signs of pseudoscience — and how does it mimic the appearance of real science?
How do you find trustworthy health information — and what sources should you avoid?

chapters.name: Evaluating Government and Official Sources
topics: How reliable are government data sources — census data, economic statistics, crime reports?
When do governments manipulate official statistics — and what are the warning signs?
How do you evaluate press releases, official statements, and government reports?
What is the difference between a government agency's data and a politician's interpretation of that data?
How do you access primary government documents — court filings, legislation, regulatory filings?
What happens to the credibility of government sources when political leaders undermine their own institutions?
How do international organizations — WHO, UN, IMF — produce data, and how reliable is it?

chapters.name: Evaluating Social Media as a Source
topics: When is social media a legitimate source of information — eyewitness accounts, breaking news, expert commentary?
How do you verify a social media post — checking the account, the timing, and the claims?
What are the signs that a social media account is a bot, a troll, or an astroturfed persona?
How do viral posts gain credibility through repetition rather than verification?
Why do screenshots of tweets, texts, and documents spread faster than the original sources — and why is that dangerous?
How does the algorithmic amplification of engagement distort which voices appear authoritative?
What questions should you ask before sharing or believing anything you see on social media?

chapters.name: Following the Money: Funding and Motivation
topics: Why does knowing who funds a source help you evaluate its credibility?
How do you find out who owns or funds a news outlet, think tank, or research organization?
What are dark money organizations — and how do they produce content that looks independent but isn't?
How do corporate-funded studies, industry-backed think tanks, and sponsored content create the appearance of objectivity?
What is native advertising — and how does it disguise advertising as journalism?
How do political donors fund media outlets and information ecosystems to advance their agendas?
What role does financial transparency play in source credibility?

chapters.name: The Ecosystem of Unreliable Sources
topics: What are the main categories of unreliable sources — partisan propaganda, conspiracy sites, content farms, and scams?
How do unreliable sources build credibility — professional-looking websites, stolen logos, and fake expert credentials?
What is a content farm — and how does it produce high-volume, low-quality content for advertising revenue?
How do conspiracy theories spread through an ecosystem of interconnected unreliable sources that cite each other?
What is information laundering — how does a false claim move from a fringe source to a mainstream one?
How do state-sponsored media outlets — RT, Xinhua, Press TV — present propaganda as legitimate journalism?
Why does the ecosystem of unreliable sources continue to grow — and what economic forces sustain it?

chapters.name: When Experts Disagree
topics: What do you do when credible experts disagree — how do you evaluate competing claims?
What is the difference between genuine scientific debate and manufactured controversy?
How do you weigh consensus against dissent — and when should you take a minority view seriously?
What role do credentials, evidence quality, and conflicts of interest play when experts disagree?
How has manufactured doubt been used by tobacco, fossil fuel, and pharmaceutical industries to delay action?
What is the Overton window — and how does it affect which expert views are considered mainstream?
How do you maintain intellectual humility when the evidence is genuinely uncertain?

chapters.name: Building Your Source Evaluation Habits
topics: What is a practical source evaluation framework you can apply to any piece of information?
How do you build a mental list of trusted sources — and how do you keep it updated?
What are the most common mistakes people make when evaluating sources — and how do you avoid them?
How do you teach source evaluation to others — family, students, community members?
What tools and browser extensions help with quick source evaluation?
How do you balance thoroughness with practicality — you can't evaluate every source deeply?
Why is source evaluation a civic responsibility — not just a personal skill?
